meta.title: Distance Learning - Mequon-Thiensville School District

body.class: fsLiveMode fsHasHeader fsHasLeftBanner fsHasFooter fsHasTwoColumnWideLeftLayout fsSection3 fsHasTheme2 district

input.name: q
input.title: search
input.style: width: 100%; padding: 0px; border: none; margin: -0.0625em 0px 0px; height: 1.25em; outline: none;

li.a: When To Keep Your Child Home
School Closings Due To Inclement Weather
Members of the Board of Education

p.span: We appreciate your patience and understanding during this time of unexpected disruption. We are very grateful for the outpouring of support from our families and community as we work together to continue to support all students!

div.class: fsDiv fsStyleTwoThirds fsStyleColumn fsStyleColumn-2 fsStyleColumn-last fsStyleAutoclear

ul.li: Educators and staff plan for distance learning
Technology needs assessed and devices made available

div.class: fsDiv fsStyleTwoThirds fsStyleColumn fsStyleColumn-2 fsStyleColumn-last fsStyleAutoclear

ul.li: Instructional focus on review of priority skills
Family check-in to ensure access to resources and learning materials
Additional technology devices available*

div.class: fsDiv fsStyleTwoThirds fsStyleColumn fsStyleColumn-2 fsStyleColumn-last fsStyleAutoclear

ul.li: Instruction includes the delivery of new content
Increase in instructional minutes for distance learning
Grading academic assignments resumes
Science and social studies instruction for grades 1-5 resumes
Attendance is recorded based on student engagement in learning
Spring standardized tests are canceled: Forward Exam (Grades 4-8 & 10), ACT Aspire (Grade 9 & 10), and MAP (Grades 1-8)

p.i: *In an effort to provide equitable access, we respectfully request families with ample technology for students at home continue to use those devices to ensure district resources are available for students who lack access. If you would like to request a device, p

i.em: lease complete the Technology Device Request Form.

div.p: While we are learning at a distance, MTSD educators will be using several technology tools. Below are some of the tools that teachers may use with your students. If you have any questions or concerns, or if you do not want your child using certain technology tools or applications, please contact your child’s teacher.
A video conferencing tool. Allows multiple individuals to connect virtually using voice and/or video. It could be used for 1:1, small-group, or whole-class interaction.

em.strong: Please take a moment to read Zoom's Privacy Policy to find out what steps the company has taken to ensure user safety.

div.p: A video-sharing tool. Teachers may use it to create interactive lessons that can be shared with students.

A video-sharing tool. Allows teachers to record and share a video. Teachers could use it to provide instruction and demonstrate problem solutions. It allows students to record work and share it with teachers.
Google Classroom: An online environment for teachers to organize and share files with students and allow students to submit work back to the teacher.
Google Docs: A word processing tool that can be shared between teacher/student and student/student.
Gmail: Email service for communication. Students in grade 4 through grade 12 have a school email account.
Google Hangouts/Meet: Video conferencing tools. It allows multiple individuals to connect virtually using voice and/or video. It could be used for 1:1, small-group, or whole-class interaction.
Google Sheets: A spreadsheet tool that can be shared between teacher/student and student/student.
Google Slides: A presentation tool that can be shared between teacher/student and student/student.

header.h2: Distance Learning Daily Time Expectations April 14 Through Return To School

table.style: border-collapse: collapse; border-color: rgb(0, 0, 0); border-spacing: 0px; border-width: 0px; border-style: solid;

br.em: Focus on Math and English Language Arts (ELA)

tr.td:
From 1 to 2 hours total per day
(less than 1 hour of screen time)
Focus on math and ELA
Incorporate science and social studies instruction in grade 1

td.strong: From 1 to 2, up to 3 hours total per day

li.em: corporate science and social studies instruction

td.p:
From 2 hours up to 4 hours total per day
(less than 3 hours of screen time)

li.em: corporate science and social studies instruction

td.em: Elementary specialists in art, music, and physical education

span.em:
will provide a list of options for students to participate in during the school closure. These options will not count toward the daily expectation for time spent engaging in distance learning.
Art: 1 grade level appropriate art activity per week
Music: 1 grade level appropriate music activity per week
Physical Education: 1 hour of physical education activities per day (keeping with the Play 60 theme and recognizing that many, if not all, athletic activities have been canceled)

table.style: border-collapse: collapse; border-spacing: 0px; border-width: 0px; border-color: rgb(0, 0, 0); border-style: solid;

li.span: Science and social studies: 45 minutes daily
AVID, music, related arts, and world languages: 30 minutes daily
Physical education: 30 minutes, 3 times per week

br.em: Each class should provide approximately 60 minutes of instruction and learning per day.

div.p: Click the links below to access technology resources for MTSD students. These resources have been approved by MTSD educators for the learning and enrichment opportunities they provide.

em.span: Experiencing tech troubles during online learning?

ul.li: Is the purpose of the lesson clear to students?
Are the learning targets/intentions or essential questions/learning outcomes stated in a manner in which students understand why they are completing the lesson?
Is the lesson aligned to course standards?
Does the lesson provide a continuum of learning toward the next learning objective?
Do students understand the connection of the work to real-world applications?
Do students have the knowledge and skills needed to complete the lesson?
Are students able to independently complete the lesson?
Does the lesson use technology familiar to the students?
Does the completion time coincide with district time expectations?
Does the quantity of work provide adequate information to assess students’ understanding and application of the concepts or procedures?
Was the lesson developed collaboratively with all members of the grade-level/content area team?
Is the opportunity present for students to apply their knowledge and skills to a new or unique situation?
Do students have multiple ways to engage in the learning?
Are higher-order thinking opportunities present?
Have teachers identified how and when they will provide feedback?
Have teachers identified how and when they will assess student learning?

a.title: Non-discrimination and Equal Opportunity
a.data-page-name: Public Notice of Non-discrimination and Equal Employment Opportunity
